reasoning:
The critique mainly targets a claim the essay only lightly leans on (that we can avoid “moral catastrophes” by better aiming/constraints, and that safety is an optional add‑on). But the core thesis is about the size/narrowness of the eutopian target (value fragility; fussiness of plausible value functions) largely abstracting away from political-economy dynamics of capability races. So centrality is low-to-moderate.

Strength is low because the critique doesn’t really engage the main argumentative supports (multiplicative fragility model; the survey of bounded/unbounded value functions and why they’re fussy). It also attributes an “aiming better avoids catastrophe” inference that the essay does not centrally make in this installment (it explicitly says navigation/steering is addressed in the next essay and here focuses on target size).

Correctness is mixed: the general point that governance/safety constraints can induce races or shift who captures resources first is plausible, but several specific attributions (treating capabilities as exogenous “and safety as an add-on,” or that the paper infers catastrophes can be avoided by aiming better) are at least overstated or misread relative to the text.

Clarity is decent but relies on compressed assertions (“arbitrary checks,” “redistribute who reaches advanced futures first”) without specifying mechanisms/evidence. Dead weight is low. It stays on one issue. Overall it poses only a minor problem for the position as written.
title: Safety constraints may accelerate dangerous actors rather than prevent moral catastrophe
